title: Stacy Keach Sr.
text:
Walter Stacy Keach Sr. (May 29, 1914 – February 13, 2003), known professionally as Stacy Keach Sr. was an American actor whose screen career spanned over five decades.
Biography.
Keach was born in <a href="Chicago%2C%20Illinois">Chicago</a>, Illinois. He was of English descent. His career ranged from 1942 to 1997, with more than seventy movie and television appearances. He and his wife, the former Mary Cain Peckham, were members of the <a href="Peninsula%20Players">Peninsula Players</a> summer theater program during the 1930s.
Keach appeared in a 1955 episode of "<a href="The%20Lone%20Ranger%20%28TV%20series%29">The Lone Ranger</a>". Keach also appeared as Sheriff Ben Mason in the 1957 episode "Last Chance" of the <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a>/<a href="Warner%20Brothers">Warner Brothers</a> <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">western</a> <a href="television%20series">television series</a>, "<a href="Colt%20.45%20%28TV%20series%29">Colt .45</a>". That same year, he was cast as Jed Hammer in the episode "Trail's End" of the ABC/WB western series, "<a href="Sugarfoot">Sugarfoot</a>", starring <a href="Will%20Hutchins">Will Hutchins</a>. Keach was cast in 1957 and 1958 in five episodes of the <a href="NBC">NBC</a> western series, "<a href="The%20Californians%20%28TV%20series%29">The Californians</a>" as Bill Coleman.
Keach is probably best known for his role as Carlson in the NBC sitcom, "<a href="Get%20Smart">Get Smart</a>". Carlson, a CONTROL scientist, was the inventor of such gadgets as an umbrella rifle (with a high-speed camera in the handle) and edible buttons—a parody of <a href="Q%20%28James%20Bond%29">Q</a>, who holds a similar position in the <a href="James%20Bond">James Bond</a> movies. By the time Keach took the role, however, he was the head of an industrial film company (a position he had held since 1948). Keach eventually gave up the role of Carlson when one too many clients were unable to reach him, and he had to respond, "I've been working in the CONTROL labs."
In 1964 he appeared on "<a href="Perry%20Mason%20%281957%20TV%20series%29">Perry Mason</a>" in the role of Lt. Gibson in "The Case of the Frightened Fisherman" and in 1965 he again appeared on "Perry Mason" in the role of the trial court judge in "The Case of the Cheating Chancellor." In 1961, he appeared as Dr. Walter in the very first episode of "<a href="The%20Dick%20Van%20Dyke%20Show">The Dick Van Dyke Show</a>". 
1973 -Adam 12. Episode. West Valley division as a night watchman.
Keach's lookalike son, <a href="Stacy%20Keach">Stacy Keach Jr.</a> (usually billed as "Stacy Keach," exactly like his father), enjoys an acting career with far greater name recognition than his father's. The younger Keach is perhaps best known for starring in the <a href="title%20role">title role</a> of the "<a href="Mickey%20Spillane%27s%20Mike%20Hammer%20%281984%20TV%20series%29">Mike Hammer</a>" television series in the 1980s and 1990s. Another son, <a href="James%20Keach">James Keach</a>, an actor, director, and producer, was married to the actress <a href="Jane%20Seymour%20%28actress%29">Jane Seymour</a>.
Keach died of <a href="congestive%20heart%20failure">congestive heart failure</a> at the age of eighty-eight in <a href="Burbank%2C%20California">Burbank</a>, <a href="California">California</a> and is buried at <a href="Forest%20Lawn%20Memorial%20Park%20%28Hollywood%20Hills%29">Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Hollywood Hills)</a>.
